elements.content: Four novel U(VI) containing coordination polymers, UO2(C7H10O4) (1), UO2(C8H12O4) (2), UO2(C9H14O4) (3), and UO2(C10H16O4) (4), were synthesized from UO2(NO3)2·6H2O and aliphatic dicarboxylic acids (pimelic, suberic, azelaic, and sebacic acids, respectively) using hydrothermal techniques and were characterized by single-crystal diffraction. Compounds 1 and 4 consist of (UO2)2O8 dimers connected by the acid molecules to form layers, whereas 2 and 3 are constructed of chains of hexagonal bipyramids connected to form layers. These materials complete the series of aliphatic uranyl carboxylates to C10 (sebacic acid) and may be considered to be carboxylate “end-members” of a series of dipyridyl/carboxylate structures described in part II of this investigation (following in this issue).
elements.clean_text: Four novel U(VI) containing coordination polymers, UO2(C7H10O4) (1), UO2(C8H12O4) (2), UO2(C9H14O4) (3), and UO2(C10H16O4) (4), were synthesized from UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O and aliphatic dicarboxylic acids (pimelic, suberic, azelaic, and sebacic acids, respectively) using hydrothermal techniques and were characterized by single-crystal diffraction. Compounds 1 and 4 consist of (UO2)2O8 dimers connected by the acid molecules to form layers, whereas 2 and 3 are constructed of chains of hexagonal bipyramids connected to form layers. These materials complete the series of aliphatic uranyl carboxylates to C10 (sebacic acid) and may be considered to be carboxylate "end-members" of a series of dipyridyl/carboxylate structures described in part II of this investigation (following in this issue).

elements.content: Four novel uranyl (UO2 2+)-containing coordination polymers constructed from aliphatic dicarboxylate linker molecules have been synthesized and characterized structurally. These compounds complete the series of uranyl dicarboxylates to C10 and demonstrate polymerization of uranyl cations to form either dimers or infinite chains.
elements.clean_text: Four novel uranyl (UO2 2+)-containing coordination polymers constructed from aliphatic dicarboxylate linker molecules have been synthesized and characterized structurally. These compounds complete the series of uranyl dicarboxylates to C10 and demonstrate polymerization of uranyl cations to form either dimers or infinite chains.

elements.content: There has been an increase in research dedicated to metal−organic framework materials (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs) in recent years. MOFs and CPs can be seen as an extension of zeolitic materials (e.g., aluminosilicates) and as such have potential applications similar to zeolites including gas storage/separation, ion exchange, catalysis, and sensing. A number of recent reviews explore some uses of metal−organic coordination polymers including chemisorption, electronic switching, magnetic ordering, and gas storage. Although the potential applications of MOFs and CPs are inspiring, contribution to the fundamental understanding of the formation of these materials, as well as an expansion of the catalog of possible structure types, is needed.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been an increase in research dedicated to metal-organic framework materials (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs) in recent years. MOFs and CPs can be seen as an extension of zeolitic materials (e.g., aluminosilicates) and as such have potential applications similar to zeolites including gas storage/separation, ion exchange, catalysis, and sensing. A number of recent reviews explore some uses of metal-organic coordination polymers including chemisorption, electronic switching, magnetic ordering, and gas storage. Although the potential applications of MOFs and CPs are inspiring, contribution to the fundamental understanding of the formation of these materials, as well as an expansion of the catalog of possible structure types, is needed.

elements.content: Metal−organic coordination polymers typically consist of a metal center or polynuclear cluster bonded to multifunctional organic linkers, which in turn assemble into extended topologies. These materials take advantage of both the coordination sphere of the metal center and the functionalities and sterics of the organic species. The majority of coordination polymeric materials to date have been based on transition metal chemistry. Well-defined coordination geometries of the d-block elements can lead to some predictability with respect to bonding preferences and ultimately to some degree of control over resulting topology. Consequently, much of the appeal and potential utility of these materials stems from the ability to design topologies of interest through appropriate pairing of metal coordination geometries with organic groups to impart desired structural motifs.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic coordination polymers typically consist of a metal center or polynuclear cluster bonded to multifunctional organic linkers, which in turn assemble into extended topologies. These materials take advantage of both the coordination sphere of the metal center and the functionalities and sterics of the organic species. The majority of coordination polymeric materials to date have been based on transition metal chemistry. Well-defined coordination geometries of the d-block elements can lead to some predictability with respect to bonding preferences and ultimately to some degree of control over resulting topology. Consequently, much of the appeal and potential utility of these materials stems from the ability to design topologies of interest through appropriate pairing of metal coordination geometries with organic groups to impart desired structural motifs.

elements.content: Actinide coordination polymers, on the other hand, and specifically those that contain uranium(VI), have not been explored as extensively as materials based on transition metal or even lanthanide compositions. U(VI) coordination chemistry in molecular materials is rather well-developed and has been reviewed in a number of settings. As a result, a few polymeric materials from previous studies are known, and more recent efforts actually targeting these topologies have begun to emerge. A particularly rich subset of U(VI) molecular materials are those containing N or O donor ligands or both, the vast majority of which utilize monofunctional (or at most chelating) ligands to give rise to molecular compounds. This richness actually serves as a guide to the formation of extended topologies and efforts to promote such compounds using multifunctional linker molecules have focused on common functional groups observed in molecular materials. Generally speaking, in this and any coordination polymer system, two types of linker molecules can be employed:  homofunctional linkers have multiple coordination sites, each of which is the same such as the aliphatic dicarboxylates presented herein. Heterofunctional linkers contain multiple, distinct binding sites and have been discussed elsewhere in the uranyl and lanthanide systems.
elements.clean_text: Actinide coordination polymers, on the other hand, and specifically those that contain uranium(VI), have not been explored as extensively as materials based on transition metal or even lanthanide compositions. U(VI) coordination chemistry in molecular materials is rather well-developed and has been reviewed in a number of settings. As a result, a few polymeric materials from previous studies are known, and more recent efforts actually targeting these topologies have begun to emerge. A particularly rich subset of U(VI) molecular materials are those containing N or O donor ligands or both, the vast majority of which utilize monofunctional (or at most chelating) ligands to give rise to molecular compounds. This richness actually serves as a guide to the formation of extended topologies and efforts to promote such compounds using multifunctional linker molecules have focused on common functional groups observed in molecular materials. Generally speaking, in this and any coordination polymer system, two types of linker molecules can be employed: homofunctional linkers have multiple coordination sites, each of which is the same such as the aliphatic dicarboxylates presented herein. Heterofunctional linkers contain multiple, distinct binding sites and have been discussed elsewhere in the uranyl and lanthanide systems.

elements.content: In addition to the potential applications of MOFs and CPs mentioned thus far, uranyl-containing materials are also being explored for their photoluminescent properties, as well as their photocatlytic activity. Emission from the uranyl center may be sensitized (and tuned) using the “antenna effect” when coordinated to ligands containing conjugated π systems. Further, oxidation of organic molecules by photoexcited uranyl cations has been known for some time and most recently used for DNA and RNA cleavage. Chen et al. have shown U−Ag coordination polymers to be photochemically active to the degradation of model pollutants. A particularly attractive feature of their system is the fact that the uranyl cation is in the solid state (as opposed to solution), thus making separations more tractable. Last, an understanding of the interaction between U(VI) and organic species under hydrothermal conditions is of general interest as this relates to nuclear waste stewardship and the nuclear fuel cycle in general.
elements.clean_text: In addition to the potential applications of MOFs and CPs mentioned thus far, uranyl-containing materials are also being explored for their photoluminescent properties, as well as their photocatlytic activity. Emission from the uranyl center may be sensitized (and tuned) using the "antenna effect" when coordinated to ligands containing conjugated π systems. Further, oxidation of organic molecules by photoexcited uranyl cations has been known for some time and most recently used for DNA and RNA cleavage. Chen et al. have shown U-Ag coordination polymers to be photochemically active to the degradation of model pollutants. A particularly attractive feature of their system is the fact that the uranyl cation is in the solid state (as opposed to solution), thus making separations more tractable. Last, an understanding of the interaction between U(VI) and organic species under hydrothermal conditions is of general interest as this relates to nuclear waste stewardship and the nuclear fuel cycle in general.

elements.content: With respect to crystal chemistry, U(VI) is commonly found as the linear triatomic (UO2 2+) cation in the solid state. The oxygen atoms of this species are typically terminal and form multiple bonds with the metal center. The uranyl oxygens are usually found at a distance of 1.6−1.8 Å from the U center with an O−U−O angle ranging from 170° to 180°. Considering that UO2 2+ is a linear species with largely terminal oxygen ligands, any further coordination to the metal center occurs only in the equatorial plane and gives rise to three common coordination geometries or primary building units:  square, pentagonal, or hexagonal bipyramids. A recurring structural theme in our materials has been the polymerization of the primary building units into larger secondary building units, such as dimers or chains. This polymerization is routinely seen in uranium oxide materials such as uranyl oxide hydrate minerals where the primary building units edge share to form sheets. Several factors influencing the degree of polymerization of the primary building units will be discussed herein, yet briefly these include concentration of U(VI), the pH of the solution, and the geometry of the organic linker.
elements.clean_text: With respect to crystal chemistry, U(VI) is commonly found as the linear triatomic (UO2 2+) cation in the solid state. The oxygen atoms of this species are typically terminal and form multiple bonds with the metal center. The uranyl oxygens are usually found at a distance of 1.6-1.8 Å from the U center with an O-U-O angle ranging from 170° to 180°. Considering that UO2 2+ is a linear species with largely terminal oxygen ligands, any further coordination to the metal center occurs only in the equatorial plane and gives rise to three common coordination geometries or primary building units: square,  pentagonal, or hexagonal bipyramids. A recurring structural theme in our materials has been the polymerization of the primary building units into larger secondary building units, such as dimers or chains. This polymerization is routinely seen in uranium oxide materials such as uranyl oxide hydrate minerals where the primary building units edge share to form sheets. Several factors influencing the degree of polymerization of the primary building units will be discussed herein, yet briefly these include concentration of U(VI), the pH of the solution, and the geometry of the organic linker.

elements.content: Several uranyl-containing dicarboxylates are known. Oxalic acid (C2H2O4) can be considered as the simplest of the dicarboxylic acids since the acid molecule does not contain any intervening −CH2− groups. There are several structures reported using this linker as well as other aliphatic dicarboxylic acids, although there are not many reported that utilize aliphatic dicarboxylates more than four carbon atoms in length. Our group has been attempting to extend the known UO2 2+−aliphatic dicarboxylate structures to include longer (greater than four −CH2− groups) aliphatic dicarboxylate linkers, both with the aim of understanding the crystal chemical systematics of this family of compounds and also as a precursor study of uranyl MOFs and CPs wherein multiple homofunctional organic linkers of varying functionality are employed. In this contribution, we report the synthesis, structural characterization, and luminescent properties of four novel U(VI)-containing coordination polymers utilizing pimelic (C7H12O4), suberic (C8H14O4), azelaic (C9H16O4), and sebacic (C10H18O4) acids. These compounds may be considered as single linker “end members” within a larger class of aliphatic carboxylate/aromatic pyridyl materials, a description of which follows in this issue.
elements.clean_text: Several uranyl-containing dicarboxylates are known. Oxalic acid (C2H2O4) can be considered as the simplest of the dicarboxylic acids since the acid molecule does not contain any intervening -CH2- groups. There are several structures reported using this linker as well as other aliphatic dicarboxylic acids, although there are not many reported that utilize aliphatic dicarboxylates more than four carbon atoms in length. Our group has been attempting to extend the known UO2 2+-aliphatic dicarboxylate structures to include longer (greater than four -CH2- groups) aliphatic dicarboxylate linkers, both with the aim of understanding the crystal chemical systematics of this family of compounds and also as a precursor study of uranyl MOFs and CPs wherein multiple homofunctional organic linkers of varying functionality are employed. In this contribution, we report the synthesis, structural characterization, and luminescent properties of four novel U(VI)-containing coordination polymers utilizing pimelic (C7H12O4), suberic (C8H14O4), azelaic (C9H16O4), and sebacic (C10H18O4) acids. These compounds may be considered as single linker "end members" within a larger class of aliphatic carboxylate/aromatic pyridyl materials, a description of which follows in this issue.

elements.content: Synthesis. Caution:  While the uranium oxynitrate hexahydrate (UO 2 (NO 3 ) 2 · 6H 2 O) used in this study contains depleted U, standard precautions for handling radioactive substances should be followed. UO2(NO3)2·6H2O was produced by oxidizing UO2 (Strem) in excess concentrated HNO3. The organic linkers were purchased and used without any further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Synthesis. Caution: While the uranium oxynitrate hexahydrate (UO  2  (NO  3  )  2  ⋅ 6H  2  O) used in this  study contains depleted U, standard precautions for handling radioactive substances should be  followed. UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O was produced by oxidizing UO2 (Strem) in excess concentrated HNO3. The organic linkers were purchased and used without any further purification.

elements.content: UO 2 (C 7 H 10 O 4 ) (1). Compound 1 was prepared by dissolving 0.25 g of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.080 g of pimelic acid (Aldrich) in 1.36 g of water. The solution (molar ratio 1:1:151) was prepared in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr bomb and then heated statically at 180 °C for 3 days. A crystalline solid was formed, collected, and washed with water and ethanol. A crystalline secondary phase was observed via powder X-ray diffraction as observed and calculated patterns were compared to assess purity. A pure sample of 1 was ultimately obtained by doubling the amount of pimelic acid in the reaction. The crystalline solid was collected and washed with water and ethanol. Yield:  54% (based on uranium). Elemental analysis (Galbraith Laboratories, Knoxville, TN), observed (calculated):  C 19.63% (19.6%); H 2.27% (2.3%).
elements.clean_text: UO  2  (C  7  H  10  O  4  ) (1). Compound 1 was prepared by dissolving 0.25 g of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 0.080 g of pimelic acid (Aldrich) in 1.36 g of water. The solution (molar ratio 1:1:151) was prepared in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr bomb and then heated statically at 180 °C for 3 days. A crystalline solid was formed, collected, and washed with water and ethanol. A crystalline secondary phase was observed via powder X-ray diffraction as observed and calculated patterns were compared to assess purity. A pure sample of 1 was ultimately obtained by doubling the amount of pimelic acid in the reaction. The crystalline solid was collected and washed with water and ethanol. Yield: 54% (based on uranium). Elemental analysis (Galbraith Laboratories, Knoxville, TN), observed (calculated): C 19.63% (19.6%); H 2.27% (2.3%).

elements.content: UO 2 (C 8 H 12 O 4 ) (2). Compound 2 was prepared in the manner described above by replacing the aliphatic acid with 0.087 g of suberic acid (Aldrich) to keep the established molar ratio. Phase purity of the resulting crystalline solid was assessed by comparing the calculated and observed powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and it was determined that an unknown secondary phase was present. A pure sample of 2 was ultimately obtained by doubling the amount of suberic acid in the reaction. The crystalline solid was collected and washed with water and ethanol. Yield:  89% (based on uranium). Elemental analysis, observed (calculated):  C 21.46% (21.7%); H 2.56% (2.73%).
elements.clean_text: UO  2  (C  8  H  12  O  4  ) (2). Compound 2 was prepared in the manner described above by replacing the aliphatic acid with 0.087 g of suberic acid (Aldrich) to keep the established molar ratio. Phase purity of the resulting crystalline solid was assessed by comparing the calculated and observed powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and it was determined that an unknown secondary phase was present. A pure sample of 2 was ultimately obtained by doubling the amount of suberic acid in the reaction. The crystalline solid was collected and washed with water and ethanol. Yield: 89% (based on uranium). Elemental analysis, observed (calculated): C 21.46% (21.7%); H 2.56% (2.73%).

elements.content: UO 2 (C 9 H 14 O 4 ) (3). Compound 3 was prepared in the manner described above by replacing the aliphatic acid with 0.094 g of azelaic acid (Aldrich), to keep the established molar ratio. Phase purity of the resulting crystalline solid was assessed by comparing the calculated and observed powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and it was determined that a secondary phase was present. Efforts were made to remove the unidentified secondary phase but proved to be unsuccessful. As a consequence, elemental analysis and percent yield calculations were deemed unreliable and thus are not reported here.
elements.clean_text: UO  2  (C  9  H  14  O  4  ) (3). Phase purity of the resulting crystalline solid was assessed by comparing the calculated and observed powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and it was determined that a secondary phase was present. Efforts were made to remove the unidentified secondary phase but proved to be unsuccessful. As a consequence, elemental analysis and percent yield calculations were deemed unreliable and thus are not reported here.

elements.content: UO 2 (C 10 H 16 O 4 ) (4). Compound 4 was prepared in the manner described above by replacing the aliphatic acid with 0.101 g of sebacic acid (Aldrich) to keep the established molar ratio. As with compounds 1 − 3, phase purity of the resulting crystalline solid was assessed by comparing the calculated and observed powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and it was determined that a secondary phase was present. Efforts were made to remove the unidentified secondary phase and as with 3, proved to be unsuccessful. As with 3, elemental analysis and percent yield calculations were deemed unreliable and thus are not reported here.
elements.clean_text: UO  2  (C  10  H  16  O  4  ) (4). Compound 4 was prepared in the manner described above by replacing the aliphatic acid with 0.101 g of sebacic acid (Aldrich) to keep the established molar ratio. As with compounds 1 - 3, phase purity of the resulting crystalline solid was assessed by comparing the calculated and observed powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and it was determined that a secondary phase was present. Efforts were made to remove the unidentified secondary phase and as with 3, proved to be unsuccessful. As with 3, elemental analysis and percent yield calculations were deemed unreliable and thus are not reported here.

elements.content: Single - Crystal X-ray Diffraction. Single crystals of each of the samples were isolated from the bulk and mounted on either a glass fiber (2) or a cryoloop (1, 3, and 4). Reflections for 2 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker P4 diffractometer equipped with an Apex CCD detector using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å) and 0.3° ω scans. The data were integrated with the SMART/SAINT software package. Reflections for 1, 3, and 4 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with an Apex II CCD detector using Mo Kα radiation and a combination 0.5° ω and φ scans. The data were integrated with the SAINT software package. The data for 1 − 4 were corrected for absorption using SADABS. Compounds 2 and 3 were solved using SIR92, whereas compounds 1 and 4 were solved using SHELXS97. All of the structures were refined using SHELXL9749 within the WINGX suite of software. Crystallographic data for compounds 1−4 are provided in Table .

The data were integrated with the SAINT software package. The data for 1 - 4 were corrected for absorption using SADABS. Compounds 2 and 3 were solved using SIR92, whereas compounds 1 and 4 were solved using SHELXS97. All of the structures were refined using SHELXL9749 within the WINGX suite of software. Crystallographic data for compounds 1-4 are provided in Table .

The heavy atoms and all other non-hydrogen atoms in each of the structures were found in Fourier-difference maps and ultimately refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms in all of the structures were placed in calculated positions and allowed to ride on their respective C atoms with a fixed C−H distance of 0.97 Å and U iso(H) = −1.2U eq(C).

The hydrogen atoms in all of the structures were placed in calculated positions and allowed to ride on their respective C atoms with a fixed C-H distance of 0.97 Å and U iso(H) = -1.2U eq(C).

elements.content: During the refinement of structure 1, considerable residual electron density was observed within 1 Å of the metal centers. Because this may be an indication of twinning, an unindexed array of reflections was tested for twinning using CELL_NOW and a second (nonmerohedral) component with a twin law of [0.262 0 −0.733 0 −1 0 −1.270 0 −0.262] was found. This second component was minor, with approximately 10% of the observed reflections attributed to the second component. Reflections were integrated using two twin components, but only the data from major component led to a model in which all the non-hydrogen atoms could be refined anisotropically. As a result, the data reported herein consider only the major component, and it has been concluded that the large residual electron density is due to the unresolved twin component.
elements.clean_text: During the refinement of structure 1, considerable residual electron density was observed within 1 Å of the metal centers. Because this may be an indication of twinning, an unindexed array of reflections was tested for twinning using CELL_NOW and a second (nonmerohedral) component with a twin law of [0.262 0 -0.733 0 -1 0 -1.270 0 -0.262] was found. This second component was minor, with approximately 10% of the observed reflections attributed to the second component. Reflections were integrated using two twin components, but only the data from major component led to a model in which all the non-hydrogen atoms could be refined anisotropically. As a result, the data reported herein consider only the major component, and it has been concluded that the large residual electron density is due to the unresolved twin component.

elements.content: Structure 4 contains disordered sebacate groups that were ultimately deemed the result of nonmerohedral twinning. An unindexed reflection array was inspected visually using RLATT, and a second, nonmerohedral component was observed, to which approximately 45% of the reflections may be attributed. CELL_NOW51 was employed to determine the twin law [−0.995 0.012 0.010 0.382 −0.099 0.917 0.461 1.076 0.094] to relate these components, and the data were integrated using a two component matrix file. During refinement of the structure, it became evident that only data from the primary component could be refined anisotropically, and therefore the final (reported) refinement is based on data from this component only. The disorder has therefore been modeled accordingly.
elements.clean_text: Structure 4 contains disordered sebacate groups that were ultimately deemed the result of nonmerohedral twinning. An unindexed reflection array was inspected visually using RLATT, and a second,  nonmerohedral component was observed, to which approximately 45% of the reflections may be attributed. CELL_NOW51 was employed to determine the twin law [-0.995 0.012 0.010 0.382 -0.099 0.917 0.461 1.076 0.094] to relate these components, and the data were integrated using a two component matrix file. During refinement of the structure, it became evident that only data from the primary component could be refined anisotropically, and therefore the final (reported) refinement is based on data from this component only. The disorder has therefore been modeled accordingly.

elements.content: Structure Descriptions Compound 1, UO2(C7H10O4), consists of (UO2)2O8 dimers connected by pimelic acid molecules to form two-dimensional sheets (Figure ). The dimers consist of two edged-shared pentagonal bipyramids containing two crystallographically unique metal centers, each of which consists of a linear UO2 2+ cation coordinated to five equatorial oxygen atoms from four pimelate molecules. The uranyl oxygens are found at an average distance of 1.762 Å from the U metal centers. The pimelate carboxylate groups are found in two coordination modes, bridging bidentate and bridging tridentate. Each of the acid molecules is bound in a bridging tridentate coordination at one end of the acid molecule and bridging bidentate coordination at the other (Figure ). The O atoms of the bridging bidentate groups (O7, O8, O11, O12) are found at an average distance of 2.274 Å from the U atom centers, whereas those from the bridging tridentate group (O5, O6, O9, O10) are slightly farther away from the metal centers at an average distance of 2.470 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Results

 Structure Descriptions Compound 1, UO2(C7H10O4), consists of (UO2)2O8 dimers connected by pimelic acid molecules to form two-dimensional sheets (Figure ). The dimers consist of two edged-shared pentagonal bipyramids containing two crystallographically unique metal centers, each of which consists of a linear UO2 2+ cation coordinated to five equatorial oxygen atoms from four pimelate molecules. The uranyl oxygens are found at an average distance of 1.762 Å from the U metal centers. The pimelate carboxylate groups are found in two coordination modes, bridging bidentate and bridging tridentate. Each of the acid molecules is bound in a bridging tridentate coordination at one end of the acid molecule and bridging bidentate coordination at the other (Figure ). The O atoms of the bridging bidentate groups (O7, O8, O11, O12) are found at an average distance of 2.274 Å from the U atom centers, whereas those from the bridging tridentate group (O5, O6, O9, O10) are slightly farther away from the metal centers at an average distance of 2.470 Å.

elements.content: ORTEP diagram of1 illustrating the numbering scheme. The ellipsoids are shown at 50% probability, and the hydrogen atoms were excluded for clarity. The symmetry codes are (i) x + 1/2, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2 and (ii) x + 1, y + 1, z + 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  ORTEP diagram of1 illustrating the numbering scheme. The ellipsoids are shown at 50% probability, and the hydrogen atoms were excluded for clarity. The symmetry codes are (i) x + 1/2, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2 and (ii) x + 1, y + 1, z + 1.

elements.content: Compound 2, UO2(C8H12O4), consists of chains (along [100]) of edge-shared hexagonal bipyramids connected by suberic acid molecules to form sheets resulting in an overall two-dimensional topology (Figure ). The hexagonal bipyramids are constructed of a central UO2 2+ cation with six equatorial oxygen atoms, which are associated with four distinct suberate molecules (Figure ). There is only one crystallographically unique U atom with the crystallographically unique uranyl oxygen atom (O1) found at a distance of 1.759(4) Å. Carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O3) found in a bridging tridentate connectivity at both ends of the acid molecule with an average U−O distance of 2.506 Å. Having only one mode of connectivity, bridging tridentate, serves as the basis for the formation of the chain of edge-shared hexagonal bipyramids.
elements.clean_text: Compound 2, UO2(C8H12O4), consists of chains (along [100]) of edge-shared hexagonal bipyramids connected by suberic acid molecules to form sheets resulting in an overall two-dimensional topology (Figure ). The hexagonal bipyramids are constructed of a central UO2 2+ cation with six equatorial oxygen atoms, which are associated with four distinct suberate molecules (Figure ). There is only one crystallographically unique U atom with the crystallographically unique uranyl oxygen atom (O1) found at a distance of 1.759(4) Å. Carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O3) found in a bridging tridentate connectivity at both ends of the acid molecule with an average U-O distance of 2.506 Å. Having only one mode of connectivity, bridging tridentate, serves as the basis for the formation of the chain of edge-shared hexagonal bipyramids.

elements.content: Compound 3, UO2(C9H14O4), consists of edge-shared hexagonal bipyramids forming chains propagating in the [010] direction, which are then linked by azelaic acid molecules to form two-dimensional sheets (Figure ). As in 2, the hexagonal bipyramids are constructed of a central UO2 2+ cation and six equatorial oxygen atoms associated with four azelate molecules (Figure ). In this structure, there is one crystallographically unique uranium site with one crystallographically unique uranyl oxygen atom (O1) found at a distance of 1.758(5) Å. As in structure 2, there are two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O3) found in a bridging tridentate coordination to the central U atom. The average U−O distance for O2 and O3 is 2.500 Å, which is similar to the average distance found in structure 2.
elements.clean_text: Compound 3, UO2(C9H14O4), consists of edge-shared hexagonal bipyramids forming chains propagating in the [010] direction, which are then linked by azelaic acid molecules to form two-dimensional sheets (Figure ). As in 2, the hexagonal bipyramids are constructed of a central UO2 2+ cation and six equatorial oxygen atoms associated with four azelate molecules (Figure ). In this structure, there is one crystallographically unique uranium site with one crystallographically unique uranyl oxygen atom (O1) found at a distance of 1.758(5) Å. As in structure 2, there are two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O3) found in a bridging tridentate coordination to the central U atom. The average U-O distance for O2 and O3 is 2.500 Å, which is similar to the average distance found in structure 2.

elements.content: Compound 4, UO2(C10H16O4), is constructed of (UO2)2O8 dimers linked by sebacate molecules to form an overall layered material (Figure ). There are three crystallographically unique uranium sites found in pentagonal bipyramid coordination (Figure ), which are bonded to their individual uranyl oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O7−O10) at an average distance of 1.710 Å. The UO2 2+ centers are connected by the sharing of the equatorial oxygen atoms to form dimers. These dimers are further connected by the sebacate molecules to form two unique layers (Figure ). The layers are distinct from each other by the way the acid molecules are coordinated to the UO2 2+ cations. In one layer (the green layer in Figure ), there are two sebacate molecules whose carboxylate groups are found in bridging tridentate coordination (O11, O12, O15, and O16, average U−O distance of 2.45 Å) at one end of the molecule and in bridging coordination at the opposite end of the molecule (O13, O14, O17, and O18, average U−O distance of 2.29 Å), similar to structure 1. In the second layer (the blue layer in Figure ), there are two unique sebacate molecules that are linked to the dimers. In this case, each sebacate molecule has only one mode of connectivity, O3 and O4 (average U−O distance of 2.31 Å) are found bridging the dimers into chains, whereas O5 and O6 (average U−O distance of 2.47 Å) are found in bridging tridentate coordination and form the shared edge of the dimer.
elements.clean_text: Compound 4, UO2(C10H16O4), is constructed of (UO2)2O8 dimers linked by sebacate molecules to form an overall layered material (Figure ). There are three crystallographically unique uranium sites found in pentagonal bipyramid coordination  (Figure ), which are bonded to their individual uranyl oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O7-O10) at an average distance of 1.710 Å. The UO2 2+ centers are connected by the sharing of the equatorial oxygen atoms to form dimers. These dimers are further connected by the sebacate molecules to form two unique layers (Figure ). The layers are distinct from each other by the way the acid molecules are coordinated to the UO2 2+ cations. In one layer (the green layer in Figure ), there are two sebacate molecules whose carboxylate groups are found in bridging tridentate coordination (O11, O12, O15, and O16, average U-O distance of 2.45 Å) at one end of the molecule and in bridging coordination at the opposite end of the molecule (O13, O14, O17, and O18, average U-O distance of 2.29 Å), similar to structure 1. In the second layer (the blue layer in Figure ), there are two unique sebacate molecules that are linked to the dimers. In this case, each sebacate molecule has only one mode of connectivity, O3 and O4 (average U-O distance of 2.31 Å) are found bridging the dimers into chains, whereas O5 and O6 (average U-O distance of 2.47 Å) are found in bridging tridentate coordination and form the shared edge of the dimer.

elements.content: Structural Systematics. This body of work completes the series of the UO2 2+ cation linked by aliphatic dicarboxylates of varying lengths, beginning with succinic acid (C4H6O4) and ending with sebacic acid (C10H18O4) (Table ). As stated above, the majority of U(VI)−aliphatic dicarboxylate structures reported to date have contained shorter dicarboxylates:  oxalic (C2H2O4), malonic (C3H4O4), and succinic (C4H6O4) acids. For this reason, this series concentrated on the longer aliphatic dicarboxylates:  glutaric (C5H8O4) to sebacic (C10H18O4) acids. UO2(C5H6O4), UO2(C6H8O4), and UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2 have been reported previously by our group, so only a short description of these structures will be given here. In UO2(C5H6O4), the UO2 2+ centers are found in pentagonal bipyramids, which are then polymerized into (UO2)2O8 dimers that are connected by the glutarate molecules to form layers. The same dimers are found UO2(C6H8O4) with the adipate molecules linking the dimers into a three-dimensional structure. In the second U−adipate structure, UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2, the UO2 2+ centers are found in monomeric hexagonal bipyramidal coordination with adipate molecules linking the uranyl cations into chains along the [001] direction and water molecules filling in the two remaining equatorial positions. We have also been able to reproduce UO2(C4H4O4)(H2O) using the same hydrothermal reaction conditions used for the current study. This uranyl succinate compound was reported previously to have been prepared from a room-temperature precipitation. UO2(C4H4O4)(H2O) contains individual pentagonal bipyramids connected by succinate molecules into a three-dimensional framework. A summary of structural features for the uranyl dicarboxylates is given in Table . We note that we have intentionally omitted oxalates and malonates from this list because the diversity of structure types and the variety of synthetic methods used to produce these compounds make comparison to longer dicarboxylate linkers inappropriate. Recent reports of uranyl oxalates and a review of uranyl-containing coordination polymers provide more information in this regard.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

 Structural Systematics. This body of work completes the series of the UO2 2+ cation linked by aliphatic dicarboxylates of varying lengths, beginning with succinic acid (C4H6O4) and ending with sebacic acid (C10H18O4) (Table ). As stated above, the majority of U(VI)-aliphatic dicarboxylate structures reported to date have contained shorter dicarboxylates: oxalic (C2H2O4), malonic (C3H4O4), and succinic (C4H6O4) acids. For this reason, this series concentrated on the longer aliphatic dicarboxylates: glutaric (C5H8O4) to sebacic (C10H18O4) acids. UO2(C5H6O4), UO2(C6H8O4), and UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2  have been reported previously by our group, so only a short description of these structures will be given here. In UO2(C5H6O4), the UO2 2+ centers are found in pentagonal bipyramids, which are then polymerized into (UO2)2O8 dimers that are connected by the glutarate molecules to form layers. The same dimers are found UO2(C6H8O4) with the adipate molecules linking the dimers into a three-dimensional structure. In the second U-adipate structure, UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2, the UO2 2+ centers are found in monomeric hexagonal bipyramidal coordination with adipate molecules linking the uranyl cations into chains along the [001] direction and water molecules filling in the two remaining equatorial positions. We have also been able to reproduce UO2(C4H4O4)(H2O) using the same hydrothermal reaction conditions used for the current study. This uranyl succinate compound was reported previously to have been prepared from a room-temperature precipitation. UO2(C4H4O4)(H2O) contains individual pentagonal bipyramids connected by succinate molecules into a three-dimensional framework. A summary of structural features for the uranyl dicarboxylates is given in Table . We note that we have intentionally omitted oxalates and malonates from this list because the diversity of structure types and the variety of synthetic methods used to produce these compounds make comparison to longer dicarboxylate linkers inappropriate. Recent reports of uranyl oxalates and a review of uranyl-containing coordination polymers provide more information in this regard.

elements.content:
Summary of Structural Features and Fluorescent Behavior

formula linker building unit a polymerization carboxylate coordination b fluorscence c refs UO2(C4H4O4)(H2O) succinate PBP bb red shift 13, 54 Li[UO2(C5H6O4)(C5H7O4)]·4H2O glutarate HBP b 63 UO2(C5H6O4) glutarate PBP dimers bb, bt red shift 42 UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2 adipate HBP b blue shift 53 UO2(C6H8O4) adipate PBP dimers bb, bt red shift 53 UO2(C7H10O4) pimelate PBP dimers bb, bt red shift this study UO2(C8H12O4) suberate HBP chains bt red shift this study UO2(C9H14O4) azelate HBP chains bt this study UO2(C10H16O4) sebacate PBP dimers bb, bt this study

a  PBP and HBP represent pentagonal and hexagonal bipyramidal geometry, respectively. b  b represents bidentate, bb represents bridging bidentate, and bt represents bridging tridentate. c  All compounds were excited at 365 and 424 nm and compared to UO2(NO3)2·6H2O.

One general characteristic of this series of structures listed in Table is the polymerization of the uranyl building unit. U(VI) is commonly found in one of three coordination spheres:  square, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramids, yet each of the structures (except UO2(C4H4O4)(H2O) and UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2) reported herein has a polymerization of either pentagonal or hexagonal bipyramids to form higher order secondary building units such as dimers or chains. Although it is difficult to know precisely which species are present at any point of a hydrothermal reaction, it is possible to increase the potential for polymerization of uranyl cations to form oligomeric secondary building units (SBUs) (and ultimately influence the overall topology) by increasing the concentration U(VI) in the solutions. This was our reasoning in a previous study, where two distinct U−adipate compounds were produced:  UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2, which contains monomeric hexagonal bipyramids, from a dilute U(VI) solution (0.025 M) and UO2(C6H8O4), a framework compound containing (UO2)2O8 dimers, from a more concentrated solution (0.368 M). In light of these observations, more concentrated solutions were used exclusively for this study in an effort to direct formation of higher order SBUs.
elements.clean_text: One general characteristic of this series of structures listed in Table  is the polymerization of the uranyl building unit. U(VI) is commonly found in one of three coordination spheres: square, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramids, yet each of the structures (except UO2(C4H4O4)(H2O) and UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2) reported herein has a polymerization of either pentagonal or hexagonal bipyramids to form higher order secondary building units such as dimers or chains. Although it  is difficult to know precisely which species are present at any point of a hydrothermal reaction, it is possible to increase the potential for polymerization of uranyl cations to form oligomeric secondary building units (SBUs) (and ultimately influence the overall topology) by increasing the concentration U(VI) in the solutions. This was our reasoning in a previous study, where two distinct U-adipate compounds were produced: UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2, which contains monomeric hexagonal bipyramids, from a dilute U(VI) solution (0.025 M) and UO2(C6H8O4), a framework compound containing (UO2)2O8 dimers, from a more concentrated solution (0.368 M). In light of these observations, more concentrated solutions were used exclusively for this study in an effort to direct formation of higher order SBUs.

elements.content: The reactions that produced the structures reported herein were all conducted with concentrated U(VI) solutions (0.368 M) and low pH values. The initial pH values for each of the reactions ranged from 1.07 for uranium adipate (UO2(C6H8O4)) to 1.77 from uranium azelate (UO2(C9H14O4)). According to UO2 2+ speciation studies, polymerization to oligomeric species (dimers, trimers, etc.) can be seen at both higher pH values and increased UO2 2+ concentrations. Considering that the initial pH values of this study consistently remained below 2.0, it may be suggested that concentration is a more important factor in the polymerization of the UO2 2+ species into secondary building units for these materials. One caveat, however, is that the referenced speciation studies explore systems at temperatures below hydrothermal, and thus these comments should be considered as speculative at present. Further, studies of aqueous uranyl systems at higher temperature (85 °C) have been reported yet at much lower concentrations and thus prohibit appropriate comparison.
elements.clean_text: The reactions that produced the structures reported herein were all conducted with concentrated U(VI) solutions (0.368 M) and low pH values. The initial pH values for each of the reactions ranged from 1.07 for uranium adipate (UO2(C6H8O4)) to 1.77 from uranium azelate (UO2(C9H14O4)). According to UO2 2+ speciation studies, polymerization to oligomeric species (dimers, trimers, etc.) can be seen at both higher pH values and increased UO2 2+ concentrations. Considering that the initial pH values of this study consistently remained below 2.0, it may be suggested that concentration is a more important factor in the polymerization of the UO2 2+ species into secondary building units for these materials. One caveat, however, is that the referenced speciation studies explore systems at temperatures below hydrothermal, and thus these comments should be considered as speculative at present. Further, studies of aqueous uranyl systems at higher temperature (85 °C) have been reported yet at much lower concentrations and thus prohibit appropriate comparison.

elements.content: In addition to these synthetic parameters, one may consider the effect of ligand geometry on the overall topology as well. It appears that the manner in which the carboxylate group is coordinated to the UO2 2+ center may be correlated to the conformation of the aliphatic chain. There are three uranyl−carboxylate coordination geometries seen in Table :  bidentate, bridging bidentate, and bridging tridentate (Figure ). Bidentate carboxylate groups only occur with monomeric building units such as UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2, and there does not seem to be any correlation to the conformation of the aliphatic chain; that is, the aliphatic molecule can be “flat” or “kinked”. A “kinked” aliphatic chain contains a rotation about the α carbon causing the chain to rotate out of the equatorial plane of the UO2 2+ centers. The bridging bidentate and bridging tridentate connectivity modes do seem to have a correlation to the conformation of the aliphatic chains, which can be seen when comparing the adipate molecules in UO2(C6H8O4). In this structure, there are two distinct acid molecules:  one molecule is “flat” and in plane with the dimer molecules, and the other molecule is “kinked” and connects the dimers into a framework (Figure ). Closer examination of the adipate molecules reveals that the “flat” molecule coordinates to the UO2 2+ center in a bridging tridentate fashion at both carboxylate groups and the “kinked” molecule is found bridging the dimers together also at both ends of the molecule. This correlation between the carboxylate coordination and chain conformation continues in structures 2 and 3, in which both structures have the acid molecules remaining “flat” and do not deviate from the equatorial plane of the UO2 2+ centers. Further, the only mode of carboxylate connectivity found in these structures is bridging tridentate.
elements.clean_text: In addition to these synthetic parameters, one may consider the effect of ligand geometry on the overall topology as well. It appears that the manner in which the carboxylate group is coordinated to the UO2 2+ center may be correlated to the conformation of the aliphatic chain. There are three uranyl-carboxylate coordination geometries seen in Table : bidentate, bridging bidentate, and bridging tridentate (Figure ). Bidentate carboxylate groups only occur with monomeric building units such as UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2, and there does not seem to be any correlation to the conformation of the aliphatic chain; that is, the aliphatic molecule can be "flat" or "kinked". A "kinked" aliphatic chain contains a rotation about the α carbon causing the chain to rotate out of the equatorial plane of the UO2 2+ centers. The bridging bidentate and bridging tridentate connectivity modes do seem to have a correlation to the conformation of the aliphatic chains, which can be seen when comparing the adipate molecules in UO2(C6H8O4). In this structure, there are two distinct acid molecules: one molecule is "flat" and in plane with the dimer molecules, and the other molecule is "kinked" and connects the dimers into a framework (Figure ). Closer examination of the adipate molecules reveals that the "flat" molecule coordinates to the UO2 2+ center in a bridging tridentate fashion at both carboxylate groups and the "kinked" molecule is found bridging the dimers together also at both ends of the molecule. This correlation between the carboxylate coordination and chain conformation continues in structures 2 and 3, in which both structures have the acid molecules remaining "flat" and do not deviate from the equatorial plane of the UO2 2+ centers. Further, the only mode of carboxylate connectivity found in these structures is bridging tridentate.

elements.content: The carboxylate coordination modes found in the series of structures listed in Table . The labeling is as follows:  (A) bridging bidentate, (B) bidentate, and (C) bridging tridentate.
elements.clean_text: 10  The carboxylate coordination modes found in the series of structures listed in Table . The labeling is as follows: (A) bridging bidentate, (B) bidentate, and (C) bridging tridentate.

elements.content: Polyhedral representation of UO2(C6H8O4)53 illustrating the “flat” adipate molecules remaining in the plane of the dimers and the “kinked” molecules connecting the layers into a framework.
elements.clean_text: 11  Polyhedral representation of UO2(C6H8O4)53 illustrating the "flat" adipate molecules remaining in the plane of the dimers and the "kinked" molecules connecting the layers into a framework.

elements.content: In structures containing dimers as secondary building units, both bridging bidentate and bridging tridentate modes of connectivity are found. UO2(C5H6O4), UO2(C7H10O4) (1), and UO2(C10H16O4) (4) have aliphatic chains that are coordinated by bridging tridentate at one end of the acid molecule and bridging bidentate at the opposite end of the molecule, and the mode of connectivity still seems to dictate the conformation of the aliphatic acid molecule. For example in 1 (Figure ), the bridging end of a pimelate molecule (O7, O8, C5−C7) contains a rotation about C6, which causes the chain to rotate (“kink”) outside of the equatorial plane of the dimers, although at the bridging tridentate end of the pimlate molecule (O5, O6, C1−C4) this rotation does not occur and the chain remains “flat.” Structure 4 is a special case because there are two crystallographically unique layers contained within the structure (above). One layer follows the trend of having a “kinked” end (O13−C20−O14 and O17−C30−O18) and a “flat” end (O11−C11−O12 and O15−C21−O16) of the sebacate molecules. In the other layer, the sebacate molecules only have one mode of connectivity but do not completely follow the trend seen in the other structures. The bridging tridentate acid group (O5, O6, C6−C10) in particular contains a rotation about C9, which causes a “kink” in the molecule but allows the acid molecule to remain in the equatorial plane of the dimers, whereas in the bridging acid groups (O3, O4, C1−C5), the rotation occurs at the O atoms causing the entire chain to be out of the plane of the dimers.
elements.clean_text: In structures containing dimers as secondary building units, both bridging bidentate and bridging tridentate modes of connectivity are found. UO2(C5H6O4), UO2(C7H10O4) (1), and UO2(C10H16O4) (4) have aliphatic chains that are coordinated by bridging tridentate at one end of the acid molecule and bridging bidentate at the opposite end of the molecule, and the mode of connectivity still seems to dictate the conformation of the aliphatic acid molecule. For example in 1 (Figure ), the bridging end of a pimelate molecule (O7, O8, C5-C7) contains a rotation about C6, which causes the chain to rotate ("kink") outside of the equatorial plane of the dimers, although at the bridging tridentate end of the pimlate molecule (O5, O6, C1-C4) this rotation does not occur and the chain remains "flat." Structure 4 is a special case because there are two crystallographically unique layers contained within the structure  (above). One layer follows the trend of having a "kinked" end (O13-C20-O14 and O17-C30-O18) and a "flat" end (O11-C11-O12 and O15-C21-O16) of the sebacate molecules. In the other layer, the sebacate molecules only have one mode of connectivity but do not completely follow the trend seen in the other structures. The bridging tridentate acid group (O5, O6, C6-C10) in particular contains a rotation about C9, which causes a "kink" in the molecule but allows the acid molecule to remain in the equatorial plane of the dimers, whereas in the bridging acid groups (O3, O4, C1-C5), the rotation occurs at the O atoms causing the entire chain to be out of the plane of the dimers.

elements.content: Fluorescence. Fluorescence studies were conducted on the uranium dicarboxylate series to explore the potential for any systematic uranyl emission behavior within this class of materials. The fluorescence experiments were conducted on a Shimadzu RF-5301 PC spectrofluorophotometer using a xenon lamp (emission wavelengths 400−800 nm; excitation slit width 1.5 nm; emission slit width 3.0 nm; high sensitivity). Samples of 1, 2, UO2(C4H4O4)(H2O), UO2(C5H6O4), UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2, and UO2(C6H8O4) were explored via direct excitation of the UO2 2+ centers at 365 and 424 nm. These spectra were referenced to that of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O excited at 365 nm for comparison of the peak positions. The spectra can be found in the Supporting Information, although the results are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text: Fluorescence. Fluorescence studies were conducted on the uranium dicarboxylate series to explore the potential for any systematic uranyl emission behavior within this class of materials. The fluorescence experiments were conducted on a Shimadzu RF-5301 PC spectrofluorophotometer using a xenon lamp (emission wavelengths 400-800 nm; excitation slit width 1.5 nm; emission slit width 3.0 nm; high sensitivity). Samples of 1, 2, UO2(C4H4O4)(H2O), UO2(C5H6O4), UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2, and UO2(C6H8O4) were explored via direct excitation of the UO2 2+ centers at 365 and 424 nm. These spectra were referenced to that of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O excited at 365 nm for comparison of the peak positions. The spectra can be found in the Supporting Information, although the results are summarized in Table .

elements.content: Uranyl fluorescence typically has a characteristic six peak spectrum relating to the S11 → S00 and S10 → S0 ν, where ν = 0−4, electronic transitions, and for UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, the most intense peak (S10 → S00) is positioned at 508 nm. Comparison of the observed spectra to the uranium oxynitrate reference showed an overall shift in each of the patterns that was independent of the excitation wavelength. The majority of the samples displayed a red shift between 4 and 11 nm. The only sample to show a blue shift (7 nm) was UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2. Additional comments regarding these fluorescence properties follow in part II of this study (this issue).
elements.clean_text: Uranyl fluorescence typically has a characteristic six peak spectrum relating to the S11 → S00 and S10 → S0 ν, where ν = 0-4, electronic transitions, and for UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O, the most intense peak (S10 → S00) is positioned at 508 nm. Comparison of the observed spectra to the uranium oxynitrate reference showed an overall shift in each of the patterns that was independent of the excitation wavelength. The majority of the samples displayed a red shift between 4 and 11 nm. The only sample to show a blue shift (7 nm) was UO2(C6H8O4)(H2O)2. Additional comments regarding these fluorescence properties follow in part II of this study (this issue).

elements.content: We have successfully synthesized a series of uranyl coordination polymers in which the UO2 2+ centers are polymerized through aliphatic dicarboxlyates. Polymerization of the primary building units into larger secondary building units, such as chains and dimers, is common in this series. Several factors, including UO2 2+ concentration and possibly sterics of the linker molecules, appear to influence the polymerization of the building units. There also is a correlation between the uranyl coordination geometry and the conformation of the aliphatic chain. This series of structures can be considered as single linker “end members” of a larger study of the coordination of UO2 2+ centers with a combination of aliphatic dicarboxylates and aromatic pryridyl species that follows in this issue.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized a series of uranyl coordination polymers in which the UO2 2+ centers are polymerized through aliphatic dicarboxlyates. Polymerization of the primary building units into larger secondary building units, such as chains and dimers, is common in this series. Several factors, including UO2 2+ concentration and possibly sterics of the linker molecules, appear to influence the polymerization of the building units. There also is a correlation between the uranyl coordination geometry and the conformation of the aliphatic chain. This series of structures can be considered as single linker "end members" of a larger study of the coordination of UO2 2+ centers with a combination of aliphatic dicarboxylates and aromatic pryridyl species that follows in this issue.

In addition, CIF files have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (http://www.ccdc. cam.ac.uk) and may be obtained by citing reference numbers 614224−614227.

elements.clean_text: References

cln_elements.content:
UO 2 (C 7 H 10 O 4 ) (1). Compound 1 was prepared by dissolving 0.25 g of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.080 g of pimelic acid (Aldrich) in 1.36 g of water. The solution (molar ratio 1:1:151) was prepared in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr bomb and then heated statically at 180 °C for 3 days. A crystalline solid was formed, collected, and washed with water and ethanol. A crystalline secondary phase was observed via powder X-ray diffraction as observed and calculated patterns were compared to assess purity. A pure sample of 1 was ultimately obtained by doubling the amount of pimelic acid in the reaction. The crystalline solid was collected and washed with water and ethanol. Yield:  54% (based on uranium). Elemental analysis (Galbraith Laboratories, Knoxville, TN), observed (calculated):  C 19.63% (19.6%); H 2.27% (2.3%).

UO 2 (C 8 H 12 O 4 ) (2). Compound 2 was prepared in the manner described above by replacing the aliphatic acid with 0.087 g of suberic acid (Aldrich) to keep the established molar ratio. Phase purity of the resulting crystalline solid was assessed by comparing the calculated and observed powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and it was determined that an unknown secondary phase was present. A pure sample of 2 was ultimately obtained by doubling the amount of suberic acid in the reaction. The crystalline solid was collected and washed with water and ethanol. Yield:  89% (based on uranium). Elemental analysis, observed (calculated):  C 21.46% (21.7%); H 2.56% (2.73%).
cln_elements.clean_text:
UO  2  (C  7  H  10  O  4  ) (1). Compound 1 was prepared by dissolving 0.25 g of UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 0.080 g of pimelic acid (Aldrich) in 1.36 g of water. The solution (molar ratio 1:1:151) was prepared in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr bomb and then heated statically at 180 °C for 3 days. A crystalline solid was formed, collected, and washed with water and ethanol. A crystalline secondary phase was observed via powder X-ray diffraction as observed and calculated patterns were compared to assess purity. A pure sample of 1 was ultimately obtained by doubling the amount of pimelic acid in the reaction. The crystalline solid was collected and washed with water and ethanol. Yield: 54% (based on uranium). Elemental analysis (Galbraith Laboratories, Knoxville, TN), observed (calculated): C 19.63% (19.6%); H 2.27% (2.3%). 

 UO  2  (C  8  H  12  O  4  ) (2). Compound 2 was prepared in the manner described above by replacing the aliphatic acid with 0.087 g of suberic acid (Aldrich) to keep the established molar ratio. Phase purity of the resulting crystalline solid was assessed by comparing the calculated and observed powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and it was determined that an unknown secondary phase was present. A pure sample of 2 was ultimately obtained by doubling the amount of suberic acid in the reaction. The crystalline solid was collected and washed with water and ethanol. Yield: 89% (based on uranium). Elemental analysis, observed (calculated): C 21.46% (21.7%); H 2.56% (2.73%).
